Award.AwardTitle: Databrary: An open video-based data-sharing system for developmental science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Behavior develops from a variety of factors interacting across domains and time scales. To capture the richness of behavioral development and understand its complexity, most developmental scientists record video. However, researchers rarely share video data, and this has slowed progress, impeded understanding, and diminished the impact of public investments in behavioral science. The Databrary project aims to increase scientific transparency and accelerate discovery in developmental science by making it easy and convenient for scientists to share video data. No large-scale repository for sharing digital video data currently exists; the researchers involved in this project will create a web-based repository (databrary.org). They will develop data management tools to make contributing video files and metadata convenient and reliable for researchers, and they will create mechanisms to enable transcoding, searching, browsing, visualizing, streaming, and downloading files from the Databrary. OpenSHAPA (openshapa.org), a free, open-source video-coding tool will become the common file format for the Databrary. The investigators will develop tools to convert data coded in other systems to the OpenSHAPA format, and they will enhance OpenSHAPA to support integration of multimedia data such as eye tracking, motion tracking, physiological measures, and brain imaging. The investigators will address cultural, historical, technical, and privacy/ethics challenges associated with open video data sharing by building a user/contributor community of developmental scientists. With community input, they will develop template permission language so that investigators can contribute datasets to the library, and they will develop contributor and user agreements to ensure appropriate levels of access. The investigators will provide training and technical support to the emerging user community through workshops, webinars, and on-site training.

By creating tools for open video data sharing, the project will deepen insights and accelerate discovery in developmental science. The contribution of a particular dataset will no longer depend on the private activities of researchers from one laboratory, but instead benefit from the critique and imagination of many researchers with different viewpoints. Researchers will be able to view one another's datasets and reanalyze them to test competing hypotheses, perform integrative analyses, learn from prior examples, and address new questions beyond the scope of the original study--enabling new possibilities for research in labs with limited financial and technical resources. Moreover, the infrastructure they develop will have broad impacts for data sharing and data management in the entire behavioral science community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To capture the richness and complexity of behavior, most developmental scientists rely on video recordings as the mainstay of their research programs. The overall goal of the Databrary project (databrary.org) is to facilitate deeper and broader scientific understanding of behavioral development, increase scientific transparency and reproducibility, and speed progress by creating the infrastructure to enable open sharing of video data, related metadata, and coding files. The project has three aims: (1) to create the infrastructure and data management tools to enable open sharing of video data among developmental scientists; (2) to expand and develop a free, open source coding tool, Datavyu (datavyu.org) to facilitate annotation, exploration, visualization, and analysis of video data; and (3) to build the capacity for data sharing and behavioral coding based on the expertise and needs of the developmental science community.

Building a free video data library. With funds from the National Science Foundation, the Databrary team created a large-scale, web-based library for sharing digital video data based on open-source tools, seeded it with initial data sets to attract users, and built mechanisms to enable transcoding, searching, browsing, visualizing, streaming, and downloading files. In addition, with input from developmental scientists and experts in research ethics, we developed both template permission language so that investigators can collect and contribute datasets to the library, and common language around levels of file access.

Developing an open-source video-coding tool. In addition, we developed Datavyu (datavyu.org), based on the OpenSHAPA and MacSHAPA predecessor programs. Datavyu is a free, platform-independent, open-source video-coding tool that is becoming the common coding file format for Databrary. Datavyu supports the integration of additional, multimedia data streams such as eye tracking, motion tracking, EEG, and EMG.

Building a community committed to sharing. Developmental scientists have not traditionally engaged in open sharing of video data; however, open data sharing is a scientific imperative and common practice in the other areas of science where it has substantially accelerated the pace of discovery. We addressed the cultural, historical, technical, and privacy/ethics challenges associated with open sharing of video data by building an engaged and diverse user/contributor community of developmental and learning scientists committed to data sharing and to the creation of standards for data access and quality. We provided training and technical support to the emerging user community through conference workshops, webinars, on-site trainings, online user forums, and hundreds of technical support calls and emails.

Databrary and Datavyu provide developmental scientists with an unprecedented set of tools for discovery. Some of the researchers who will benefit come from institutions without substantial resources to support scientific research. Moreover, we are helping to deepen insights and speed progress in developmental science. The contribution of a particular dataset will no longer depend on the private analytic and interpretive activities of researchers from one laboratory, but instead will benefit from the critique and imagination of many researchers with different viewpoints. This strengthens the credibility of the research enterprise as a whole. Researchers will be able to view one another’s datasets and reanalyze them to test competing hypotheses, perform integrative analyses, learn from prior examples, and address new questions beyond the scope of the original study. By enabling increased transparency in behavioral research, we will raise the profile of developmental and behavioral science and bolster interest in and support for scientific research among the public at large.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2017
Modified by: Karen Adolph

By enabling increased transparency in behavioral research, we will raise the profile of developmental and behavioral science and bolster interest in and support for scientific research among the public at large.
